data.title: Atom automatically remove blank lines at the end of a file when save
data.body: I intentionally added some blank lines at the end of a file,but when I save the file, Atom removed them left only one.I'm using version 0.139.0.

data.title: Load the default themes when configured themes don't exist
data.body: This behavior is great for safe mode so I figured we could extend it to non-safe-mode when the configured themes aren't available for some reason. This will prevent the UI from looking wonky if things are mis-configured.

data.title: Spike on converting packages to new APIs
data.body:
Status: Converting find-and-replace. Taking notes for the upgrade guide

While some parts of the API are not 100% finished, I think this is something we should spike on before we declare the API frozen. 

Yesterday @kevinsawicki was telling me how painful it was converting wrap-guide to the new APIs. He said most of the issue was with `workspaceView` related stuff: we heavily rely on `$.fn.find` in the specs. I dont remember the deets of the rest of the pain, so elaboration would be :+1:. 

I think @nathansobo and I should do a couple packages so we feel the pain package authors will feel, and can adjust APIs as necessary, or come up with patterns to ease pain.

Also, @kevinsawicki I didnt think of it at the time, but there is a forward compatible way to get the element: 

``` coffee
workspaceElement = atom.workspace.getView(atom.workspace)
```

Then `workspaceElement.querySelector` is the dude.

data.title: :memo: fix TextEditor::delete() doc
Atom keeps clogging (crashing) when making use of save-all.
data.body:
After editing a multiple files (under 2MB) and pressing save-all Atom would crash briefly, depending on the load or extent of the save I guess, but it happens even if the rest are already saved. I tried it on Atom 0.135 - Ubuntu and 0.139 - Windows 7 (main PC). It crashed on my main computer which can definitely handle the load.

Also take note that issue https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/3798 still persists.

data.title: Atom default font does not look the same on Linux as on Windows and Mac
data.body:
I just cloned the latest version of Atom after being away for a few weeks and I noticed that the font rendering looked a bit weird. 

On Mac OS X, I found that the font Atom was using was (very close to if not the same as) `Inconsolata, Monaco, Consolas, 'Courier New', Courier` and when I entered that for the font style on Linux, I got a rockwell looking font which has the following CSS `Rockwell, "Courier Bold", Courier, Georgia, Times, "Times New Roman", serif`. 

Here is a screenshot of the font on Linux in the settings (which appears to be the same as on Mac and Windows) 
![screenshot from 2014-10-25 12 01 42](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6335521/4780265/5cd00e0e-5c60-11e4-89c1-f3ea30485336.png)

and here is the font rendered in the editor itself which looks completely different
![screenshot from 2014-10-25 12 02 09](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6335521/4780267/67ef54de-5c60-11e4-9274-01e2ce250e4f.png)

data.title: problem in Chinese input with Toggle Soft Wrap
data.body:
When edit markdown docs, if Toggle Soft Wrap is active, get no problem with English input, it will auto change to new line. But if input Chinese,  it can't auto change to new line when reach right edge of editor, it will be longer line than it can display.

I found it seems problem with number of characters. For example, Atom display 100 English characters in one line, it will display 100 characters of Chinese in one line too. But one Chinese character will take twice room to display than English character.So it should change to new line when characters reach 50.

Hope someone can fix it.    --Ubuntu 64bit

data.title: Adding underscore to default non-word characters
data.body: I'm using undescores regularly in ruby, where you would usually write them like `SOME_MADE_UP_CONSTANT = true`, jumping between words in that variable works nicer (for me, that is) when i can navigate the individual words.

data.title: right click on a file can open the directory right-click menu instead
data.body:
When you right click onto the blank space at the left, or slightly above or below the text, the directory right-click menu opens instead:
![s1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4958615/4778967/2f6fd558-5c0f-11e4-86d9-b833c047ebe4.png)

Normal behaviour is seen when rightclicking onto text:
![s2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4958615/4778968/3522e648-5c0f-11e4-82c2-39ba983a930c.png)

data.title: Autocomplete only works on last selection if multiple insertion points are active
data.body:
**Platform:** Ubuntu GNOME 14.04, 64-bit
### Basic steps to repro
1. Create multiple insertion points (e.g. ctrl-click)
2. Attempt to use a snippet
3. Only the last insertion point made will have the snippet, and that snippet will not overwrite the prefix of that last occurence.
### Expected behavior

All insertion points will produce that snippet, overwriting the prefix triggering it, as would normally happen with a single insertion point.
### Observed behavior

(vertical bar == insertion point, [text] == selected text)

**Snippet:** `me` → `module.exports.$1 = $1`

Before expansion:

```
me|
me|
me|
```

After expansion:

```
me
me
memodule.exports.| = |
```

Should be:

```
module.exports.| = |
module.exports.| = |
module.exports.| = |
```

---

**Snippet:** `noop` → `function () {}`

Before expansion:

```
noop|
noop|
noop|
```

After expansion:

```
noop
noop
noopfunction () {}|
```

Should be:

```
function () {}|
function () {}|
function () {}|
```

---

**Snippet:** `fn` → `function ${1:name}(${2:args}) {\n  ${3://body}\n}`

Before expansion:

```
fn|
fn|
fn|
```

After expansion:

```
fn
fn
fnfunction [name](args) {
  //body
}
```

Should be:

```
function [name](args) {
  //body
}
function [name](args) {
  //body
}
function [name](args) {
  //body
}
```

---

I use the multiple insertion point feature somewhat extensively, given it's very high usefulness when refactoring code.

Here's a use case: you've copied a list of names in mult-cursor mode, and you could use a snippet to create a bunch of similar classes based on the list's contents and then export them all with ease in not much more time than just one. I know it isn't a common case, but it can become useful.

Also, if you happen to use a common snippet for, say, `get` → `getElementsByTagName`, you wouldn't have to type it out in multi-cursor mode.

data.title: Enter key does not work in Atom 139.0 on Windows 8.1
data.body: Just as the title says, there are no modifications in my keymaps.cson either.

data.title: Bug in Markdown Links where URL has Parenthesis
data.body:
In Atom 0.139.0 on Macintosh Yosemite 10.10:

This link doesn't work correctly – the internal parenthetical should be ignored for closing the markdown link. Instead, the closing parenthesis in the valid URL closes the entire markdown link, causing the link to be bad and the closing .pdf to be rendered as text.

```
["A Taxonomy of Privacy"](https://www.law.upenn.edu/journals/lawreview/articles/volume154/issue3/Solove154U.Pa.L.Rev.477(2006).pdf).
```

data.title: Syntax Highlighting - Escape Quote Messing Up in Long Line
data.body:
In the very long line, escape string disturb syntax highlighting. For example the line below (MySQL), ``` INSERT INTO `wp_microbenotesposts` VALUES (1,1,'2014-10-24 11:26:58','2014-10-24 11:26:58','Welcome to WordPress. This is your first post. Edit or delete it, then start blogging!','Hello world!','','publish','open','open','','hello-world','','','2014-10-24 11:26:58','2014-10-24 11:26:58','',0,'http://localhost/microbenote/?p=1',0,'post','',1),(2,1,'2014-10-24 11:26:58','2014-10-24 11:26:58','This is an example page. It\'s different from a blog post because it will stay in one place and will show up in your site navigation (in most themes). Most people start with an About page that introduces them to potential site visitors. It might say something like this:\n\n
Hi there! I\'m a bike messenger by day, aspiring actor by night, and this is my blog. I live in Los Angeles, have a great dog named Jack, and I like piña coladas. (And gettin\' caught in the rain.)
\n\n...or something like this:\n\n
The XYZ Doohickey Company was founded in 1971, and has been providing quality doohickeys to the public ever since. Located in Gotham City, XYZ employs over 2,000 people and does all kinds of awesome things for the Gotham community.
\n\nAs a new WordPress user, you should go to your dashboard to delete this page and create new pages for your content. Have fun!','Sample Page','','publish','open','open','','sample-page','','','2014-10-24 11:26:58','2014-10-24 11:26:58','',0,'http://localhost/microbenote/?page_id=2',0,'page','',0),(3,1,'2014-10-24 11:27:28','0000-00-00 00:00:00','','Auto Draft','','auto-draft','open','open','','','','','2014-10-24 11:27:28','0000-00-00 00:00:00','',0,'http://localhost/microbenote/?p=3',0,'post','',0); ``` The line below it will be parsed (highlighted) as string. ![screenshot from 2014-10-25 06 47 26](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3030950/4777875/41a139e2-5bd8-11e4-9aa6-22d1bd448ebb.png)

![hit-carriage-return-atom](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/224739/4775573/31d6f78c-5bb9-11e4-85ba-8d26ea49860c.gif)

data.title: Support unicode combining characters
data.body:
Adds support for editing [combining characters](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Combining_character).

This mirrors the support added for variation sequences in #3565 

Closes #3945

data.body: Was skimming https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/docs/apm-rest-api.md and didn't see it in there.

data.body: At least on windows

data.title: Update linux.md
data.body:
You need to have python2 installed on Arch.

Otherwise you get build ENOENT errors using npm-gyp.

data.title: Not letting me type
data.body:
Hey guys,

I've had Atom for one or two months and all of a sudden it will go to a block cursor that won't let me type unless I spam multiple letters (so not ctrl + or Fxx or anything like that just a-z). And I does it on start-up as well as randomly during my codin' so I'm guessing it's nothing I'm doing, does anyone know what's going on?

My release of Atom: 0.139.0

data.title: Open multiple files from fuzzy finder
data.body:
Hi guys, 

from another IDE I am using I like the feature to have multiple files opened at one time. This works by pressing Shift and Arrow up/down to mark them and then simply Enter to open. A new tab for each file will then be opened. 

Regards Benedikt

data.title: Use Bluebird instead of Q ?
data.body: The [bluebird](https://github.com/petkaantonov/bluebird) is a promise library focused on performance and can be in ordder of magnitudes [faster](https://github.com/petkaantonov/bluebird/blob/master/benchmark/stats/latest.md) than Q, it also has many useful APIs.

data.title: Getting extra line when breaking a long string (Python)
data.body:
Getting weird behaviour when breaking a long string in python. I would expect the text to appear to the right of the cursor on the next line, not a new line.

Windows 0.139.0.

![weird](http://i.imgur.com/XsqBME3.gif)

data.title: Cursor is not aligned with characters.
data.body:
When I click on the last space on [this line](https://github.com/smockle/dotfiles/blob/master/.bash_profile#L197), my cursor is placed in the middle of the space character (i.e. the cursor is improperly aligned--screenshots attached).

I was originally using the "Unity" UI theme with the "Base16 Tomorrow Light" syntax theme. My font size was set to 11 and the inspector said I was using the Inconsolata font.

I can reproduce this issue 100% of the time:

I completely closed Atom, then opened the same file again, and reproduced the issue. I switched to the "Atom Light" UI and syntax themes, and still had the issue. I closed Atom, moved my ~/.atom directory to ~/.atom.bak, then opened the same file again with a fresh Atom profile, and still reproduced the issue.

I'm running Atom 0.139.0 on a fully up-to-date OS X Yosemite 10.10. `apm -v` gives the following information:

```
apm  0.106.0
npm  1.4.4
node 0.10.32
python 2.7.8
git 2.1.2
```

![unity](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3104489/4763858/97a8c24e-5b18-11e4-90c6-28af62a1d931.png)
![atom light](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3104489/4763860/9c32604a-5b18-11e4-9a56-b324adf19690.png)
![atom default](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3104489/4763861/9effb3a4-5b18-11e4-8e4f-7f332349b689.png)

data.title: Give scoped user settings a priority
data.body:
Currently, the user's config file is loaded, then when each package loads, their config settings are loaded on top. Packages that define scoped settings will have priority over the user settings because they are loaded last. Example: atom/settings-view#267 We have a few options:
- Load the user config _after_ all the packages. 
  - This produces a period of time when atom has no styles.
  - Requires adding a pretty awkward method on PackageManager to get a callback when the scoped settings are all loaded
- Load the config as it is today, then reload the user config 
  - Requires adding a pretty awkward method on PackageManager to get a callback when the scoped settings are all loaded
  - Loads the file 2x
- Keep track of the read config file, and reload the scoped properties when the packages load 
  - Requires that awkward method
  - Seems like it would add some complexity to config
- Give the user configs an explicit higher priority
  - This PR

This feels like the cleanest, least intrusive way to do it. 

Closes atom/settings-view#267
Depends on https://github.com/atom/scoped-property-store/pull/6

data.title: Render text editor contents inside shadow DOM
data.body:
Closes #1800
## Tasks
- [x] Fix git diff styling
- [x] Fix specs
- [x] Fix loss of ability to insert text after autocompleting when the menu doesn't pop up
- [x] Add a feature flag

data.title: Add Dockerfile to build an RPM on CI
data.body:
Follow on to #3797

Adds a Dockerfile to build and upload the RPM using a Fedora 20 image.

The Debian Dockerfile was moved to `build/debian/Dockerfile`, since this one will be actively used I decided to put it at the root of the repo.

data.title: Experience Feedback
data.body:
I am seriously considering to stop using Atom, and abandon all hope on this editor.
- _It is very volatile, and I am spending more time maintaining Atom than actually coding_

```
Updating to “minimap@3.3.4” failed.Show output…
Updating to “preview@0.13.3” failed.Show output…
```
- _7 out of 10 times packages fail to update._

```
### windows 7
>apm -v
apm  0.106.0
npm  1.4.4
node 0.10.32
python 2.7.8
git 1.9.4.msysgit.2
visual studio 2012
```

IMHO I think you guys should slow down step back, put your thinking hats on and then come up with something stable and reliable.
- _Major Changes v0.139.0 (2014-10-22)_

```
Scoped language settings such as tab length are now editable from the Settings view.
Fixed an issue where clicking below the last line in the editor didn't move the cursor to the end of the file.
Fixed an issue where closing a window caused application menus to disappear for the remaining open windows.
Fixed an issue on Linux where the application menu items no longer worked.
Fixed an issue on Linux where the initial font size was too large on HDPI monitors.
Fixed an issue where the Markdown preview view would stop updating if dragged to another pane.
Fixed an issue where @page directives in SCSS files would not be colorized correctly.
```

Really Major Changes? Priorities from you guys are totally wrong, if I can't install, update packages I don't care that my Markdown Preview-er does not work properly or SCSS files colorization is incorrect.
- _Final Thoughts_

Probably will have to switch back to sublime.

data.title: syntax highlighting - strings - issue related to `%%`
data.body:
It seems to create multiple nested string syntax highlights... and since my theme uses a semi-transparent background for the string highlights, you can clearly see that they are piling up on top of each other because they get darker and darker throughout the file:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/185923/4749272/8e338880-5a81-11e4-8de2-5cb9d319ff76.png)
